author: 80raghavendra
content: <@!259648573401071617> Can you please point me to the code that generates a multiproof, given a indices of leaf nodes?

author: s1na
content:
<@!689635476826619924> sure, these are an implementation of the older "turboproof" format and haven't been updated to the most recent spec:
JS: https://github.com/ewasm/biturbo/blob/merklize-mainnet-blocks/src/multiproof.ts#L161
Rust: https://github.com/gballet/multiproof-rs/blob/master/src/lib.rs#L117

author: rimeissner
content: hey, I am following this more on the side, but do you have a document that has some basic information/ motivation? (maybe that could be pinned here ðŸ˜‰ ) I would love to understand this topic better and would need an entry point ðŸ˜‰

author: s1na
content:
Hey <@!317706410680909834>! A more comprehensive doc is probably in order, but these are the existing ones I'm aware of:
- The 1.x blog series often mentions the topics, e.g. section "Code Chunking" here https://blog.ethereum.org/2020/01/28/eth1x-files-the-stateless-ethereum-tech-tree/
- Blog post I wrote some time ago https://medium.com/ewasm/evm-bytecode-merklization-2a8366ab0c90
- More data: https://ethresear.ch/t/some-quick-numbers-on-code-merkelization/7260

author: s1na
content: The main motivation is reducing block witness size in eth1x and more accurate pricing for which parts of code are executed
